Mr. Desai joined MongoDB in November 2025 as President and Chief Executive Officer, succeeding Dev Ittycheria. Prior to MongoDB, he served as President of Product and Engineering at Cloudflare, Inc. and was President and Chief Operating Officer at ServiceNow, Inc., where he helped scale revenue from roughly $1.5 billion to over $10 billion. Earlier in his career, Mr. Desai held executive roles at EMC Corporation and Symantec Corporation, and began his technology career at Oracle Corporation.

Mr. Berry was appointed CFO of MongoDB in May 2025. Before joining MongoDB, he held CFO roles at Netapp, McAfee, FireEye, Infomatica, IO, SolarWinds, and i2 Technologies. Earlier in his career, Mr. Berry held roles at Reynolds & Reynolds, Comdata, and MoneyGram International, bringing more than 25 years of public company and operational finance experience across the technology sector. He currently serves on the boards of Rapid7 and Calix.

Mr. Pech joined MongoDB in 2017 as GVP of EMEA before being promoted to CRO in February 2019. As of December 2024, Mr. Pech was appointed as President of Field Operations, helping oversee global sales and customer success. Prior to joining MongoDB, he was the SVP of Worldwide Sales at Fuze and held sales leadership roles at BazaarVoice, BMC Software, and BladeLogic.

Mr. Capombassis has served as Chief Revenue Officer at MongoDB since December 2024, responsible for global go-to-market strategy and revenue execution. He joined MongoDB in 2017 as SVP of Americas Enterprise Sales before later holding the position as EVP of North America and EMEA Growth in February 2019. Prior to MongoDB, he spent over a decade in enterprise sales at Red Hat and IBM, focused on open-source and cloud software.

Mr. Scharf was appointed CTO of MongoDB in October 2023 following over 17 years at AWS, where he was one of the first six employees and held engineering leadership positions including VP of Amazon Identity and GM of Amazon DynamoDB, among other roles. Prior, Mr. Scharf held various technology consulting and software engineering roles.

Ms. Petry has served as CMO of MongoDB since May 2025, before joining the company in 2022 as VP of Digital and Growth Marketing and SVP of Revenue Marketing as of November 2024. Prior to MongoDB, she was VP of Marketing at FinancialForce, overseeing digital web strategy and demand generation. Previously, she held senior marketing roles at Pure Storage, HP, Yahoo, and Sun Microsystems.

We assign MDB a Moderately Aggressive Risk/Wealth Accumulation (MA/ACC) suitability rating, as MongoDB competes in a growing market with rapidly changing dynamics.

MongoDB operates in a highly competitive and rapidly evolving database market against legacy and modern database specialists, hyperscaler cloud providers, and emerging open-source or niche providers. These competitors can have deep customer relationships, strong brand equity, and the ability to bundle database services with adjacent offerings. As MongoDB expands its product portfolio and generative AI capabilities, intensifying competition from both established platforms and cloud providers could seek to capture developer workloads.

MongoDB's business model relies on renewing and expanding customer usage, particularly within MongoDB Atlas, which accounts for the majority of sales. The usage-based model can result in volatile revenue trends and reduce visibility as consumption levels can fluctuate with macro and workload dynamics. MongoDB's purposeful push toward enterprise accounts could have a lengthier sales cycles and higher customer acquisition costs that could offset efficiency gains in its land-and-expand motion.

MongoDB can increasingly expand its indirect sales motion through global system integrators, value-added resellers, and independent software vendors alongside its direct enterprise sales force. While this model enhances reach and scalability, it also introduces dependency on partner engagement and execution. Channel partners may prioritize competing offerings or fail to effectively market MongoDB's products, which could slow deal velocity or compress margins. Sustained growth can require MongoDB to balance its channel expansion with direct-sales investment and maintain alignment across partners to preserve sales efficiency and customer experience.

MongoDB competes directly with open source and do-it-yourself database solutions that provide free or low-cost alternatives to its managed offerings. Developers and enterprises may opt for these solutions in environments with budget constraints or in-house technical capability. This dynamic can slow conversion to paid Atlas tiers and limit demand. Sustaining growth can require MongoDB to clearly articulate the performance, scalability, and operational efficiency benefits of its commercial platform versus community or internally managed alternatives.

Subscription revenue grew 19% y/y to $609M, above Street of $576M, as Atlas increased 30% y/y (75% of revenue) to $470M driven by large customer momentum in the U.S. and EMEA. Non-Atlas grew 22% and was aided by multi-year deals; total revenue grew 19% y/y to $628M, above Street of $594M. Gross margin was 74.2%, while Subscription gross margin was 77.9%. EBIT was $123M, or 19.6% margin, above Street $72M, due to revenue outperformance. EPS of $1.32 was above Street of $0.82. DBNRR increased 100bps q/q to 120%. $100k-plus ARR Accounts increased 16% y/y to 2,694, and added 2,600 customers to 62,500-plus. The company generated $140M of free cash flow in the quarter with a 22.3% margin. Guidance for FY26 was raised with revenue expected to grow 21% y/y to $2.434-2.439B (was $2.340-2.360B), EBIT

of $436.4-440.4M (was $321-331M), or 18.0% margin, and EPS of $4.76-4.80 (was $3.63-3.73)

Subscription revenue increased 23% y/y to $572M, above Street of $537M. Atlas increased 29% y/y (74% of revenue) to $439M, behind strong consumption trends in May and momentum with large customers in the US. Total revenue grew to $591M (up 24% y/y), above Street of $554M, benefiting from multi-year Non-Atlas deals. DBNRR of 119% was flat q/q. $100k-plus ARR accounts grew 17% y/y to 2,564, and added 2,800 customers to 59,900-plus (300 added via Voyage AI acquisition). Gross margin was 73.8% while Subscription gross margin was 77.6%. EBIT increased 65% y/y to $87M (14.7% margin), above Street of $60M, due to revenue outperformance. EPS came in at $1.00, above Street of $0.65, and cash generated in the quarter was $70M, or 11.8% margin.

Subscription revenue of $531M was up 22% y/y, above Street of $512M, with Atlas growing 26% y/y (72% of revenue) to $396M due to strong consumption trends in February and March. Total revenue of $549M grew 22% y/y, above Street of $528M. Gross margin was 74.1% and Subscription gross margin was 77.7%. EBIT was $87M with a 15.9% margin, and above Street of $58M, aided by revenue out performance and timing of expenses. EPS of $1.00 was higher than Street of $0.07 and $105M of free cash was generated in the quarter, or 19.3% margin. DBNRR of 119% was up 100bps q/q. Accounts with $100k-plus in ARR grew 17% y/y to 2,506 and the company added 2,600 customers to 57,100-plus. Additionally, the board authorized $800M for share repurchases, bringing the total buyback program to $1,000M.

All statements in this report attributable to Gartner represent Raymond James' interpretation of data, research opinion or viewpoints published as part of a syndicated subscription service by Gartner, Inc., and have not been reviewed by Gartner. Each Gartner publication speaks as of its original publication date (and not as of the date of this research report). The opinions expressed in Gartner publications are not representations of fact, and are subject to change without notice.

Analyst Compensation : Research analysts and associates at Raymond James are compensated on a salary and bonus system. Several factors enter into the compensation determination for an analyst, including: i) research quality, ii) team productivity, iii) client feedback, iv) rating accuracy, v) overall revenue and profitability levels of the department and firm (a portion of which is generated by investment banking activities) and vi) compensation levels for comparable research analysts at competing firms. Registration of Non-U.S. Analysts : The analysts listed on the front of this report who are not employees of, or associated with, RJA are not registered/qualified as research analysts under FINRA rules and are not subject to FINRA Rule 2241 restrictions on communications with covered companies, trading securities held by a research analyst account, and obligations related to identifying and managing conflicts of interest.

This global disclosure considers all entities of Raymond James and its affiliates. The jurisdiction where the analyst(s) is registered will determine what is permitted. For example, if the persons responsible for the content of this report are not licensed as research analysts in accordance with applicable rules promulgated by the regulatory organization(s) where this report is distributed, any client wishing to effect trades in any security should contact their Raymond James representative. The analysts Mark Cash and Adam Tindle, primarily responsible for the preparation of this research report, attest to the following: (1) that the views and opinions rendered in this research report reflect his or her personal views about the subject companies or issuers and (2) that no part of the research analyst's compensation was, is, or will be directly or indirectly related to the specific recommendations or views in this research report.

We value MDB using an EV/Revenue multiple relative to peers. We also consider a DCF analysis.

Following are some general risk factors that pertain to the businesses of the subject companies and the projected target prices and recommendations included on Raymond James research: (1) Industry fundamentals with respect to customer demand or product/service pricing could change and adversely impact expected revenues and earnings; (2) issues relating to major competitors or market shares or new product expectations could change investor attitude toward the sector or this stock; (3) Unforeseen developments with respect to the management, financial condition or accounting policies or practices could alter the prospective valuation.

Moderate Risk/Provide Income (M/INC) Larger capitalization, lower volatility (beta) equities of companies with sound financials, consistent earnings, and dividend yields meaningfully above that of the S&P 500. Many securities in this category are structured with a focus on providing a consistent dividend or return of capital. Moderate Risk/Wealth Accumulation (M/ACC) Larger capitalization equities of companies with sound financials, consistent earnings growth, the potential for long-term price appreciation, and often a dividend yield. Moderately Aggressive Risk/ Provide Income (MA/INC) Generally equities of companies that are structured with a focus on providing a dividend meaningfully above that of the S&P 500. These companies typically feature sound financials, positive earnings, and the potential for long-term price appreciation. Moderately Aggressive Risk/Wealth Accumulation (MA/ACC) Generally equities of companies in fast growing and competitive industries with less predictable earnings (or losses), potentially more

leveraged balance sheets, rapidly changing market dynamics, and potential risk of principal. Aggressive Risk/Provide Income (A/INC) Generally equities of companies that are structured with a focus on providing a meaningful dividend but may face less predictable earnings (or losses), more leveraged balance sheets, rapidly changing market dynamics, financial and competitive issues, higher price volatility (beta), and meaningful risk of loss of principal. Securities of companies in this category may have a more volatile income stream from dividends or distributions of capital. Aggressive Risk/Wealth Accumulation (A/ACC) Generally equities of companies with a short or unprofitable operating history, limited or less predictable revenues, high risk associated with success, high volatility (beta), potential significant financial or legal issues, and the meaningful risk of loss of principal.

RJL has developed a proprietary algorithm for risk rating individual securities. The algorithm utilizes data from multiple vendors, and all data is refreshed at least monthly. Accordingly, suitability ratings are updated monthly. The suitability rating shown on this report is current as of the report's published date. In the event that a suitability rating changes after the published date, the new rating will not be reflected until the analyst publishes a subsequent report.
